quotes.topic_title: Codex as a software engineering teammate
quotes.text: Codex is OpenAI's coding agent. We think of Codex as just the beginning of a software engineering teammate.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Frames a long-term product vision: position coding agents as end-to-end teammates across the software lifecycle, not just code generators.

quotes.topic_title: Codex as a software engineering teammate
quotes.text: Starting to see glimpses of the future where we're actually starting to have Codex be on call for its own training.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A concrete example of operationalizing agents beyond coding—using them in real on-call/infra workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Codex as a software engineering teammate
quotes.text: One of the most mind-blowing examples of acceleration, the Sora Android app, like a fully new app, we built it in 18 days and then 10 days later, so 28 days total, we went to the public.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Provides a specific speed benchmark practitioners can use to calibrate what “agent-accelerated” delivery can look like.

quotes.topic_title: Codex as a software engineering teammate
quotes.text: One of our major goals with Codex is to get to proactivity. If we're going to build a super system, has to be able to do things.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Highlights a practical north star for agent product design: shift from reactive assistance to proactive execution.

quotes.topic_title: Codex as a software engineering teammate
quotes.text: It turns out the best way for models to use computers is simply to write code. And so we're kind of getting to this idea where if you want to build any agent, maybe you should be building a coding agent.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A counterintuitive strategy: treat “coding” as the universal interface for agents to operate computers effectively.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we chat about what it's truly like to build product at OpenAI, how Codex allowed the Sora team to ship the Sora app, which became the number one app in the app store in under one month.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete example of Codex enabling a high-impact product launch with a clear outcome metric (hit #1 in the App Store in under a month).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, the 20x growth Codex is seeing right now and what they did to make it so good at coding, why his team is now focused on making it easier to review code, not just write code, his AGI timelines, his thoughts on when AI agents will actually be really useful, and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive product focus shift—optimizing for code review (quality/control) rather than only code generation—plus a notable growth data point (20x).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: WorkOS turns those deal blockers into drop-in APIs with a modern developer platform built specifically for B2B SaaS.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS read)
quotes.context: A practical product framing: identify enterprise “deal blockers” and convert them into standardized, easy-to-integrate APIs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Whether you're a seed stage startup trying to land your first enterprise customer or a unicorn expanding globally, WorkOS is the fastest path to becoming enterprise ready and unlocking growth.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS read)
quotes.context: Actionable positioning advice: enterprise readiness can be treated as a growth unlock at any stage, not just late-stage scaling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They're essentially Stripe for enterprise features.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS read)
quotes.context: A memorable analogy that offers a mental model for how to think about bundling and abstracting complex infrastructure into a developer-first platform.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Fin is the highest performing AI agent on the market with a 65% average resolution rate.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Fin read)
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark practitioners can use to evaluate AI support automation performance.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Fin works on any help desk with no migration needed, which means you don't have to overhaul your current system or deal with delays in service for your customers.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Fin read)
quotes.context: Implementation guidance: reduce adoption friction by choosing tools that integrate without requiring disruptive migrations.

quotes.topic_title: What’s different about building at OpenAI
quotes.text: By far, I would say the speed and ambition of working at OpenAI are just dramatically more than what I can imagine.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Sets a high bar for what “fast and ambitious” can actually mean in practice, useful for recalibrating expectations and operating cadence.

quotes.topic_title: What’s different about building at OpenAI
quotes.text: But I have to say, working in OpenAI just made me reimagine what that even means.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A reminder that “moving fast” is relative—and exposure to higher-performing environments can reset your standards and methods.

quotes.topic_title: What’s different about building at OpenAI
quotes.text: The most obvious thing that comes to mind is just the explosive growth of Codex itself.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Points to a concrete example of rapid scaling as a forcing function for product and execution decisions.

quotes.topic_title: What’s different about building at OpenAI
quotes.text: I think it's a while since we bumped our external number, but it's like the 10x-ing of Codex's scale was just super fast in a matter of months and it's well more since then.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A specific growth data point that illustrates the speed/scale expectations and the operational implications of hypergrowth.

quotes.topic_title: What’s different about building at OpenAI
quotes.text: But I think one thing I've realized at OpenAI is the amount of impact that we can have and, in fact, need to have to do a good job is so high that I have to be way more ruthless with how I spend my time now.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization principle: when potential impact is massive, you must be more outcome-driven and ruthless with time allocation.

quotes.topic_title: Bottoms-up experimentation and fuzzy planning
quotes.text: But here, I think because we don't exactly know what capabilities will even come up soon and we don't know what's going to work technically, and then we also don't know what's going to land even if it works technically, it's much more important for us to be very humble and learn a lot more empirically and just try things quickly. And the org is set up in that way to be incredibly bottoms up.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A contrarian rationale for prioritizing rapid experimentation and bottom-up execution over upfront planning in highly uncertain product/tech environments.

quotes.topic_title: Bottoms-up experimentation and fuzzy planning
quotes.text: What I'm hearing is this ready, fire, aim is the approach more than ready, aim, fire.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for shipping early to learn usage patterns before investing in polish or scale.

quotes.topic_title: Bottoms-up experimentation and fuzzy planning
quotes.text: Yeah. Okay, to use this analogy a little bit, I feel like there is an aim component, but the aim component is much fuzzier.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A practical planning approach: keep directionality, but accept low precision when the future is hard to predict.

quotes.topic_title: Bottoms-up experimentation and fuzzy planning
quotes.text: he likes to say that at OpenAI, we can have really good conversations about something that's a year plus from now, and there's a lot of ambiguity in what will happen, but that's a right sort of timeline. And then we can have really good conversations about what's happening in low months or weeks. But there's this awkward middle ground, which was as you start approaching a year, but you're not at a year where it's very difficult to reason about, right?
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A novel time-horizon framework: long-term and near-term can be clear, while the mid-term is uniquely unreliable for planning.

quotes.topic_title: Bottoms-up experimentation and fuzzy planning
quotes.text: That's the place where we're much more like, "Let's find out empirically."
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Actionable product guidance: when user behavior is uncertain, default to empirical discovery rather than speculation.

quotes.topic_title: Talent density as an enabler of autonomy
quotes.text: The key is you all hire the best people in the world. And so that feels like a really key ingredient in order to be this successful at bottoms up work.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights talent density as a prerequisite for making a bottoms-up, experimental operating model work.

quotes.topic_title: Talent density as an enabler of autonomy
quotes.text: So I think the way that OpenAI runs, you can't read this or listen to a podcast and be like, "I'm just going to deploy this to my company."
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Warns practitioners against copy-pasting operating models without matching underlying conditions.

quotes.topic_title: Talent density as an enabler of autonomy
quotes.text: Maybe this is a harsh thing to say, but I think very few companies have the talent caliber to be able to do that.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that autonomy-heavy models depend on unusually high individual capability and drive.

quotes.topic_title: Talent density as an enabler of autonomy
quotes.text: So it might need to be adjusted if you were going to implement this.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Actionable takeaway: adapt the model to your org’s talent density rather than adopting it wholesale.

quotes.topic_title: Codex product definition and proactivity vision
quotes.text: More broadly, we think of Codex as what it currently is just the beginning of a software engineering teammate.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Frames the product as an evolving “teammate” rather than a point tool, guiding roadmap and UX decisions toward end-to-end ownership.

quotes.topic_title: Codex product definition and proactivity vision
quotes.text: To make that a little more fun, one thing I like to imagine is if you think of what Codex is today, it's a bit like this really smart intern that refuses to read Slack and doesn't check Datadog or Century unless you ask it to.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why context + monitoring integrations matter if you want users to trust agentic coding.

quotes.topic_title: Codex product definition and proactivity vision
quotes.text: And so we think of this as proactivity and one of our major goals with Codex is to get to proactivity.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Defines a clear north star—proactivity—as the differentiator from reactive, prompt-driven copilots.

quotes.topic_title: Codex product definition and proactivity vision
quotes.text: I like to joke today that AI products, and it's a half joke, they're actually really hard to use because you have to be very thoughtful about when it could help you.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Counterintuitive critique: the main UX problem isn’t capability, it’s the cognitive burden of deciding when to invoke AI.

quotes.topic_title: Codex product definition and proactivity vision
quotes.text: And if you think of how many times the average user is prompting AI today, it's probably tens of times. But if you think of how many times people could actually get benefit from a really intelligent entity, it's thousands of times per day.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A concrete usage gap that motivates building “helpful by default” systems instead of prompt-first interfaces.

quotes.topic_title: Codex growth, usage scale, and integrated research
quotes.text: In fact, it's been 20x since then.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A concrete growth metric that signals the magnitude of Codex’s post-launch adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Codex growth, usage scale, and integrated research
quotes.text: Also, the Codex models are serving many trillions of tokens a week now, and it's basically our most served coding model.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A scale datapoint that indicates heavy real-world usage and product-market pull.

quotes.topic_title: Codex growth, usage scale, and integrated research
quotes.text: One of the really cool things that we've seen is that the way that we decided to set up the Codex team was to build a really tightly integrated product and research team that are iterating on the model and the harness together.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: An org/design methodology: tightly coupling product and research to iterate faster on the full system.

quotes.topic_title: Codex growth, usage scale, and integrated research
quotes.text: And it turns out that lets you just do a lot more and try many more experiments as to how these things will work together.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A practical takeaway that integrated teams increase experimentation throughput and learning speed.

quotes.topic_title: Codex growth, usage scale, and integrated research
quotes.text: And so we've reached a point where actually the Codex model is the most served coding model in the API as well.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A specific adoption milestone showing the model’s success beyond first-party tooling into API customer usage.

quotes.topic_title: Why local-first onboarding beat cloud delegation
quotes.text: My analogy for this is, going back to this teammate analogy, it's like if you hired a teammate, but you're never allowed to get on a call with them and you can only go back and forth asynchronously over time.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why “cloud delegation” can be powerful but adoption-hostile without real-time interaction.

quotes.topic_title: Why local-first onboarding beat cloud delegation
quotes.text: But the key unlock is actually first you need to land with users in a way that's much more intuitive and trivial to get value from.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A product-growth principle: prioritize immediate, low-friction value before pushing users toward the long-term vision.

quotes.topic_title: Why local-first onboarding beat cloud delegation
quotes.text: So the way that most people discover, the vast majority of users discover Codex today is either they download an IDE extension or they run it in their CLI and the agent works there with you on your computer interactively.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A concrete go-to-market/onboarding lesson: meet users in their existing workflows (IDE/CLI) to drive adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Why local-first onboarding beat cloud delegation
quotes.text: It just turns out that this was one of those places where the signal we got from dogfooding is a little bit different from the signal you get from the general market
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that internal dogfooding can mislead product decisions when your team’s workflows differ from mainstream users.

quotes.topic_title: Why local-first onboarding beat cloud delegation
quotes.text: And so now when we build, we still get a ton of signal from dogfooding internally, but we're also very cognizant of the different ways that different audiences use the product.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A practical methodology: keep dogfooding, but explicitly adjust for audience differences to avoid overfitting to internal power users.

quotes.topic_title: Model advances plus the full agent stack
quotes.text: It is awesome both because it is for any given task that you were using GPT-5.1-Codex for, it's roughly 30% faster at accomplishing that task.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A concrete performance data point practitioners can use to benchmark model upgrades beyond “feels smarter.”

quotes.topic_title: Model advances plus the full agent stack
quotes.text: But I will say it's like some of how we're thinking about this is evolving a little bit from being like, "Yeah, we're just going to think about the model and let's just train the best model," to really thinking about what is an agent actually overall?
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A reframing from model-centric optimization to end-to-end agent performance as the real unit of value.

quotes.topic_title: Model advances plus the full agent stack
quotes.text: But then actually we need to serve that model through an API into a harness, and both of those things also have a really big role here.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A practical “full stack” mental model: model quality alone won’t deliver outcomes without API + harness design.

quotes.topic_title: Model advances plus the full agent stack
quotes.text: But compaction is actually a feature that uses all three layers of that stack.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: An actionable methodology: treat key capabilities (like long-running work) as cross-layer features, not model-only tricks.

quotes.topic_title: Model advances plus the full agent stack
quotes.text: So if you want to train a model to be good at all the different ways it could work, maybe you have a strong opinion that it should work using semantic search. Maybe you have a strong opinion that it should call bespoke tools or maybe you have, in our case, a strong opinion that it should just use the shell and work in the terminal, you can move much faster if you're just optimizing for one of those worlds.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Counterintuitive product strategy: pick one tool paradigm and optimize deeply rather than trying to generalize across harnesses.

quotes.topic_title: Winning strategy: super assistant plus deep GUIs
quotes.text: So I think we need to get to this world where you kind of just have an AI teammate or super assistant that you just talk to and it just knows how to be helpful on its own. So you don't have to be reading the latest tips for how to use it, you've plugged it in and it just provides help.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A product strategy frame: win by making AI self-updating and self-serving so users don’t need to track new capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Winning strategy: super assistant plus deep GUIs
quotes.text: I actually think Chat is a very good interface when you don't know what you're supposed to use it for.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Counterintuitive UI insight: chat excels as the default entry point under uncertainty, before routing to specialized tools.

quotes.topic_title: Winning strategy: super assistant plus deep GUIs
quotes.text: So you can chat with a super assistant about whatever topic you want, whether it be coding or not. And then if you are a functional expert in a specific domain such as coding, there's a GUI that you can pull up to go really deep and look at the code and work with the code.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A practical interface methodology: combine a general chat “router” with deep, domain-specific GUIs for expert workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Winning strategy: super assistant plus deep GUIs
quotes.text: I'm just going to ask it for help and it'll surface to me the best way that it can help at this point in time and maybe even chime in when I didn't ask it for help.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Actionable product principle: reduce feature/connector complexity by having the assistant choose the right mode and become proactive.

quotes.topic_title: Why every agent becomes a coding agent
quotes.text: So basically, if we're going to build a super assistant, it has to be able to do things.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A crisp requirement framing: assistants only matter if they can take real actions, not just generate text.

quotes.topic_title: Why every agent becomes a coding agent
quotes.text: And one of the learnings I think we've seen over the past year or so is that for models to do stuff, they're much more effective when they can use a computer.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A practical design principle for agent builders: give models a computer interface to reliably affect the world.

quotes.topic_title: Why every agent becomes a coding agent
quotes.text: And another way, it turns out the best way for models to use computers is simply to write code.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway: code-first control can be more reliable than point-and-click automation for agents.

quotes.topic_title: Why every agent becomes a coding agent
quotes.text: So here's the really cool thing about agents writing code is that you can import code. Code is composable, interoperable.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A reusable-systems mental model: treating agent capabilities as composable modules enables scaling beyond one-off automations.

quotes.topic_title: Why every agent becomes a coding agent
quotes.text: An example would be if we're looking at a crash reporting tool, hitting a connector for it, every sub-team probably has a different meta prompt for how they want the crashes to be analyzed.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Concrete example showing why team-level configurability (prompts/standards) is essential for deploying agents in real orgs.

quotes.topic_title: Agents beyond coding and engineers as power users
quotes.text: So I think coding agents are pretty great. I think we're seeing a ton of value there.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A grounded counterpoint to skepticism: focus on where agents already deliver clear ROI (coding) rather than dismissing the whole category.

quotes.topic_title: Agents beyond coding and engineers as power users
quotes.text: And then I think agents outside of coding, it's still very early. And this is just my opinion, but I think they're going to get a whole lot better once they can use coding too in a composable way.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A product-direction framework: non-coding agents may improve dramatically by gaining composable coding capabilities as a general-purpose tool layer.

quotes.topic_title: Agents beyond coding and engineers as power users
quotes.text: It's kind of the fun part of when you're building for software engineers, at my startup, we were building for software engineers too for a lot of that journey, and they're just such a fun audience to build for because they also like building for themselves and are often even more creative than we are in thinking about how to use the technology.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A practical audience insight: engineers act as power users who self-extend your product and invent new use cases you can learn from.

quotes.topic_title: Agents beyond coding and engineers as power users
quotes.text: So by building for software engineers, you get to just observe a ton of emergent behaviors and things that you should do and build into the product.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A methodology for product discovery: watch how engineers actually use tools to surface emergent behaviors worth turning into first-class features.

quotes.topic_title: Impact on engineering jobs and code review bottleneck
quotes.text: But as we make code even more ubiquitous, it's actually just going to be used for many more purposes. And so there's just going to be a ton more need for humans with this competency.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A contrarian take that AI may increase (not decrease) demand for coding skills as software expands into more domains and use-cases.

quotes.topic_title: Impact on engineering jobs and code review bottleneck
quotes.text: But I think what we can do basically as a product team building in the space is just try to always think about how are we building a tool so that it feels like we're maximally accelerating people rather than building a tool that makes it more unclear what you should do as the human?
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A practical product-building framework: optimize for human acceleration and role clarity when introducing AI into workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Impact on engineering jobs and code review bottleneck
quotes.text: So then you end up reviewing AI code. And that's often a less fun part of the job for many software engineers.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Highlights the emerging bottleneck shift from writing code to reviewing it—and the morale/UX cost practitioners should anticipate.

quotes.topic_title: Impact on engineering jobs and code review bottleneck
quotes.text: Well, we can ship a code review feature that helps you build confidence in the AI written code.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Actionable advice for toolmakers: invest in review/validation features that increase trust in agent output.

quotes.topic_title: Impact on engineering jobs and code review bottleneck
quotes.text: If you're thinking about this from perspective, "How do I empower the human? How do I make them feel as accelerated as possible?" You obviously see the image first. You shouldn't be reviewing the code unless first you've seen the image, unless maybe it's been reviewed by an AI and now it's time for you to take a look.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A concrete UX methodology for agent review: prioritize higher-level validation (e.g., preview) before diving into diffs, potentially after AI pre-review.

quotes.topic_title: Spec-driven vs chatter-driven development futures
quotes.text: Well, it's like often collaborate with it first to write a plan.md, like a markdown file that's your plan. And once you're happy with that, then you ask it to go off and do work. And if that plan has verifiable steps, it'll work for much longer.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable workflow for getting coding agents to reliably execute longer tasks by front-loading planning and verification.

quotes.topic_title: Spec-driven vs chatter-driven development futures
quotes.text: I think spec-driven development is an interesting idea. It's not clear to me that it'll work out that way because a lot of people don't like writing specs either, but it seems plausible that some people will work that way.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A contrarian check on the assumption that “writing specs” will become the universal interface for AI-driven engineering.

quotes.topic_title: Spec-driven vs chatter-driven development futures
quotes.text: A bit of a joke idea though is if you think of the way that many teams work today, they often don't necessarily have specs, but the team is just really self-driven and so stuff just gets done. And so almost that it's like, I'm coming up with this on the spot, so it's not a good name, but chatter-driven development where it's just like stuff is happening on social media and in your team communications tools. And then as a result, code gets written and deployed.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable alternative model—“chatter-driven development”—where ambient signals replace formal specs as the driver of execution.

quotes.topic_title: Spec-driven vs chatter-driven development futures
quotes.text: Other times I might just want to say like, "Hey, here's the customer service channel and tell me what's interesting to know, but if it's a small bug, just fix it." I don't want to have to write a spec for that, right?
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A practical example of delegating triage + small fixes directly from support signals, bypassing heavyweight product processes.

quotes.topic_title: Spec-driven vs chatter-driven development futures
quotes.text: And in this world, basically what your job is is just to plug in this app into every single signal system or system of record, and then you just sit back and swipe.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A provocative “approval interface” mental model for solopreneurship with agents: connect signals, then focus on lightweight decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Contextual assistance, Slack workflows, and validation limits
quotes.text: But I think actually auto completion and IDEs is one of the most successful AI products today. And part of what's so magical about it is that when it can surface ideas for helping you really rapidly, when it's right, you're accelerated. When it's wrong, it's not that annoying. It can be annoying, but it's not that annoying. So you can create this mixed initiative system that's contextually responding to what you're attempting to do.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A practical product design heuristic: mixed-initiative assistance works when correct suggestions accelerate users and incorrect ones are low-cost to ignore.

quotes.topic_title: Contextual assistance, Slack workflows, and validation limits
quotes.text: So for instance, when I think about launching a browser, which we did with Atlas, in my mind, one of the really interesting things we can then do is we can then contextually surface ways that we can help you as you're going about your day.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Extends the autocomplete pattern beyond IDEs into browsing, suggesting a workflow where help is triggered by real-time context rather than explicit prompts.

quotes.topic_title: Contextual assistance, Slack workflows, and validation limits
quotes.text: So we see this now. We have a Slack integration for Codex. People love if there's something that you need to do quickly, people will just @ mention Codex, "Why do you think this bug is happening?" It doesn't have to be an engineer. Even maybe data scientists often here are using Codex a ton to just answer questions like, "Why do you think this metric moved? What happened?" So questions, you get the answer right back in Slack. It's amazing, super useful. But as for when it's writing code, then you have to go back and look at the code.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: Concrete example of high-adoption workflow (Slack @mentions) and the boundary where trust/review becomes the limiting factor (generated code).

quotes.topic_title: Contextual assistance, Slack workflows, and validation limits
quotes.text: So the real, I think, bottleneck right now is validating that the code worked and writing code review.
quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.context: A clear constraint model for agent autonomy: progress is gated less by generation and more by verification and review capacity.
